column1: #! Descriptions of config data items, for use when debugging etc.
#! Entries are tab-separated, with fields as follows (some of which may be

column2: Used internally only.
Used as part of the information on the copyright page, via the About parameter in the Sword config file.  Calculated from various other elements.
??? An intermediate calculated value, which returns a formatted version stepChangesMadeByUsInDerivedWork if the latter is defined, and otherwise an empty string.
Used to hold the line of admin data which is stored as a comment near the top of Sword config files.
Used to obtain a list of book names and abbreviations from an external metadata source where available.
Present date / time in specific format.
Used to hold complex information about the conversion processing
Holds a relative data path pointing to data within the module zip file.
Set to Yes on copyright texts.
Language code plus script code and / or country code where appropriate.  (To date, this has never done anything with script- or country- codes.)
Used internally to hold digests of the input files.
2-character language code.
column9: Determined from name of root folder.

column2: 3-character language code.
column9: Determined from name of root folder.

column2: Language name in English.
column9: Determined from language code in name of root folder.

column2: Today's date.
Used internally when creating the Sword config file.
The basic module name plus various flags to distinguish release modules from evaluation ones etc.
This module cannot be used in offline STEP.
Set to hold details of those features in the text which osis2mod needs to be aware of.
Set to USX, VL, OSIS, etc, reflecting the input data used on this run.
Used to hold the encryption key to be used when generating the module.
Determines whether we use the STEP version of osis2mod or the Crosswire version.
column9: Deduced from the type of module being generated.

column2: Gives the software version number reported by osis2mod.  Used for admin purposes, so we know which osis2mod was used.
Distinguishes major and minor releases.
Used internally to hold mapping details for run-time reversification.
Indicates whether to apply runtime, conversion-time or no reversification.
column9: if conversionTimeReversification is set to yes on the command line, then conversion-time is used.  Otherwise all STEP modules use runtime reversification, and all public modules use none.  Conversion-time has not been exercised currently.

column2: Indicates which version of the STEP software is required to display the module.
Used to hold details of any special features which need to appear in the Sword config file.  (At the time of writing, does not appear to be used).
LToR, RToL or BiDi.  Aggravating that we need this alternative form, but there we are.
column9: Deduced from stepTextDirection.

column2: The new revision number for the module.
Holds details of where the source came from.  Involves some fairly fiddly processing to allow for the fact that different modules may have different information available.
Set to 'y' if the text is being up-issued.  The processing will normally work this out for itself, but you can force the issue using stepForceUpIssue.
If yes, indicates that the text has used runtime reversification.
Used internally to hold some markup information which I think may be needed only until STEPBible can be fixed.
Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
Used only in the OSIS header (and I'm not sure it’s useful there).  You can specify it, but the default (of today's date) is probably good enough.
Abbreviated name of the owning organisation.  (We use the full name if the abbreviated name is not available.)
Full name of the owning organisation.
Details of text owner and / or link to their website as HTML.
Where the text comes from a repository, the abbreviated name of the repository organisation.  (We use the full name if the abbreviated name is not available.)
Full name of the repository organisation, if there is one.
Details of repository organisation and / or link to their website as HTML.
Basic information which feeds into the Sword About parameter and thence into our copyright page (ie information typically provided by the text supplier to describe the text).
column9: With DBL texts, may be derived from metadata.xml.

column2: Says, for instance, that the text is covered by a CC licence.
column6: Not policed, but should be drawn from a list which appears in the Crosswire documentation.

column2: Optional notes giving more details about the distribution licence etc.
Indicates that this is (or is to be treated as) a copyright text.
Date on which licence expires.
column9: Used for admin purposes only.  With DBL data, this can be deduced automatically from license.xml.

column2: Licence id.
column9: Used for admin purposes only.  With DBL data, this can be deduced automatically from license.xml.

column2: A brief description of the copyright status.
A short promotion for the text supplier -- perhaps naming them and linking to their website.
Some suppliers require us to use particular words to acknowledge the fact that we have made changes in our version.
English form of abbreviated Bible name.
Vernacular form of abbreviated Bible name.
English form of full Bible name.
Vernacular form of full Bible name.

The brief description of the Bible which appears on the Bible chooser in STEP.  Typically made up of a number of elements, but you can override that by specifying a value for stepBibleDescriptionAsItAppearsOnBibleListOverride.
column9: Typically you allow this to be calculated, because the format is complicated.  But particularly when updating older modules, you may want to keep the previous value, in which case you can specify that value in a configuration file.

column2: Versification scheme.  This is used only with public modules, when it needs to be one of the schemes supported by osis2mod and must be a reasonable fit.
column6: One of the versification schemes supported by Crosswire.
column9: Needed when creating a public-facing module.  For STEP-internal modules, this parameter is set internally to a name which reflects the name of the module.

column2: Any id supplied by the source repository or owner organisation to identify this text.
column9: On DBL texts, something relevant may be available in metadata.xml.

column2: Any version number for the text supplied by the source repository or the owning organisation.

For admin purposes, we use a text-supplier's id for a text where available.  However, there is no guarantee that another text supplier may not use this same id.  stepDisambiguatorForId allows you to specify a string which is prepended to the id which hopefully will make clashes less likely.  If you don't supply something, the processing will determine a value for itself, although the absolute backstop is to use the string 'Unknown'.
Country code for module.
A script code for the module.
LTR, RTL or BiDi (currently we've never used BiDi).  May be specified, defaulted, or calculated.
column9: The system will try to work this out by examining the input if necessary.

column2: May occur multiple times.  Lines should be of the form 'stepOsisRegex=regex=>replacement'.  Each statement defines a modification to be applied to the input data before processing.
An XSLT stylesheet used to pre-process theinput data where where we are starting from OSIS.
May occur multiple times.  Lines should be of the form 'stepOsisRegex=regex=>replacement'.  Each statement defines a modification to be applied to the OSIS before processing.
An XSLT stylesheet used to pre-process the OSIS file where we are starting from OSIS.

A string of the form 'mapping | mapping | …' where each mapping looks like 'para:li4 -> para:li1' or  note -> specialNote to change a given _USX_ tag or tag and style attribute.  You can also specify eg tag:attr -> tag, to remove the attribute altogether.
Used when processing VL to indicate how comments (if any) are marked in the VL text.
Regular expression which defines how lines in VL format should be parsed.   Needs to hold named capturing groups called bookAbbrev, chapter, verse and text.
If Yes, restructures the text to conform to NRSVA structure.
Occasionally it is impossible to get osis2mod to run under control of the program in the IDE.  This lets you pause at the point where osis2mod is required in order to run it manually.
By default, if the reason for generating a new module is the same as that used last time, the module is not up-issued.  Give this as 'yes' if you want to force the issue.
Says whether it is ok to generate footnotes (depending upon licence conditions, it may not be).
column5: No if copyright text, otherwise yes.
column9: You can force the matter by overtly specifying a value.

column2: Indicates the type of footnotes to be generated on verses affected by reversification.
column9: Needed when performing conversion time or runtime reversification.

column2: Used to force the processing to use vernacular formats for any references which it generates.  You will seldom want this to be Yes, because obtaining details of how references are formatted is onerous.
Determines whether out-of-order verses are reported as an error.
column9: Sometimes translators may deliberately put verses out of order, and we may need to accept this.  However, this works only for STEP-internal modules.

column2: Set this to yes if STEP has added morphology.  Used to include this fact on the copyright page.
Set this to yes if STEP has added Strongs.  Used to include this fact on the copyright page.
Path to the location of the Crosswire version of osis2mod.
column9: I'm not sure whether we can get away without this, relying on the program to be in the path.  I'm assuming not because of needing to pick up the right DLLs on Windows.

column2: Path to the location of the STEP version of osis2mod.
column9: I'm not sure whether we can get away without this, relying on the program to be in the path.  I'm assuming not because of needing to pick up the right DLLs on Windows.

column2: It may be convenient to store _all_ data under a given folder.  If you define this variable to identify that folder, you can then use relative paths elsewhere, and have things work relative to this one.  That way, it's easy to move everything to a new location if necessary.
For DBL texts, give Dbl here.  Other repository organisations may be added in future.  Used to make it possible to pick up definitions directly from the metadata files supplied by the organisation.

For Biblica texts, give Biblica here.  Other owning organisations may be added in future.  Used to make it possible to pick up definitions related to this organisation, and to apply organisation-specific corrections to texts.
Checks the SHA-256 of the present inputs against those for the previous version of the module.
If yes, the run simply scores the text against the schemes available in Crosswire's osis2mod.
The root folder holding data for the module.
Used where we have non-OSIS inputs available, but nonetheless want to start from the current OSIS.
column9: Where alternative inputs are available, you will be warned if you opt to use OSIS and the other inputs are more up to date.

column2: Text to be recorded on History line to explain why the module has been generated (used when the new module has been occasioned by STEP itself).
Where the new module is being produced because the supplier has changed things, details of those changes.
The default version of Sword software needed to render the module.  There is a default value for this, so you shouldn't normally need to set it.
Determines whether we are building a STEP-internal or a public facing module.
column9: Needed only where the root folder name ends in PublicStep, indicating that both forms of module can be built from the same source data.  In this case, says which should be built.

column2: The callout to be used for cross-reference footnotes.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: The callout to be used for explanation footnotes.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: The callout to be used for maps.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: The callout to be used for study notes.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: The callout to be used for translation notes.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: The callout to be used for variant text notes.
column6: Arbitrary string.  Can also use specific values to force callouts to be a, b, c, etc.
column9: May want to change this to suit the vernacular.

column2: Limits the run to processing only selected books (may possibly work only with USX input).
column6: List of book abbreviations, book range, etc.

column2: Used to add debug attributes to XML nodes to assist with debugging.
Outputs information which may be of use when trying to debug config data.
Used to display active reversification rows for debugging purposes.
Used to indicate what flavour of versification we believe the text follows, so as to be able to check whether the correct reversification rows are selected.  Actually of very limited use.

column1: # External data paths and URLs.  With the exception of Reversification data, in general these aren't used or will be fixed.  They are available if you need to refer out to them from your own config file.

column2: Points to the list of Bibles available from Crosswire.  Not used currently so far as I can see.
Points to the list of commentaries available from Crosswire.  Not used currently so far as I can see.
Points to the list of devotionals available from Crosswire.  Not used currently so far as I can see.
Points to Crosswire website.
Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
column9: This is required in the OSIS header.  In fact the value they specify (which is the one I use) no longer exists, so it's a bit pointless.

column2: Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
column5: The URL of the tab-separated form of the reversification data within the STEP repository.

column2: Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.
column5: The URL of a portion of the tagging data within the STEP data repository.

column2: Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.

column5: The URL of the STEP repository.

column2: Path from which to obtain reversification data.  May be a URL or a local file; I recommend the former so you are always using the most recent data.

column2: Standard wording explaining we may have changed the versification structure.
column5: Standard text already supplied in one of the configuration files.

column2: Standard text explaining that we did the conversion.
column5: Standard text already supplied in one of the configuration files.

column2: Standard rubric thanking people who have supplied texts.
column5: Standard text already supplied in one of the configuration files.

column2: Standard text thanking Crosswire for their software etc.
column5: Standard text already supplied in one of the configuration files.

column2: Probably always going to be Bible.
